Description: Fragment of bowl and foot of South Ionian pottery shallow dish or plate; plain ring foot; slipped, worn, on interior; interior: most of forepart of a siren to left; face and neck hair in outline, reserved plumage on body and curiously thin, raised wing; variety of large rosettes as filling ornament; no trace of added colour. Exterior: two bands on lower wall; foot reserved; single band on underside.
Curator's comments: The available space on the tondo suggests that this is an unusual siren, not a sphinx, unless depicted as a protome. The style is close to that of 1965,0930.499. Probably North Ionian, if not Aeolian.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.962)
Acquisition name: Exchanged with: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
Acquisition notes: Obtained from the Ashmolean Museum in exchange for fragment B102.26.
